member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasMagma`1
member.summary: An algebraic structure supporting a binary operation with no further guaranteed properties.
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasAssociativity`1
member.summary:
A magma whose binary operation is associative. The binary operation must fulfill the following for all X and Y:
X.Op(Y).Op(Z) == X.Op(Y.Op(Z)) (associativity)
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasCommutativity`1
member.summary:
A magma whose binary operation is commutative. The binary operation must fulfill the following for all X and Y:
X.Op(Y) == Y.Op(X) (commutativity)
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasNeutralElement`1
member.summary:
A magma whose binary operation has a neutral element. The binary operation must fulfill the following for all X and Y:
X.Neutral().Op(Y) == Y (left-neutrality) X.Op(Y.Neutral()) == X (right-neutrality)
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasSemigroup`1
member.summary: A semigroup whose binary operation is associative.
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasMonoid`1
member.summary: A semigroup which has a neutral element with respect to the binary operation.
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasGroup`1
member.summary: A monoid which supports a unary inversion operator with respect to the associative binary operation.
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasCommutativeGroup`1
member.summary: A monoid which supports a unary inversion operator with respect to the associative binary operation.
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasSemilattice`1
member.summary: A semi-lattice, which is commutative, associative, and idempotent.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IMagma`1
member.summary: An algebraic structure supporting a binary operation with no further guaranteed properties.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IMagma`1.Op(`0,`0)
member.summary: The binary operation. This operation should not change either operand.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IAssociative`1
member.summary:
A magma whose binary operation is associative. The binary operation must fulfill the following for all X and Y:
m.Op(m.Op(X,Y),Z) == m.Op(X, m.Op(Y,Z)) (associativity)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.ICommutative`1
member.summary:
A magma whose binary operation is commutative. The binary operation must fulfill the following for all X and Y:
m.(X, Y) == m.Op(Y, X) (commutativity)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.INeutralElement`1
member.summary:
A magma whose binary operation has a neutral element. The binary operation must fulfill the following for all X and Y:
m.Op(m.Neutral, X) == Y (left-neutrality) m.Op(X, m.Neutral) == X (right-neutrality)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.

member.name: P:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.INeutralElement`1.Neutral
member.summary: Returns the neutral element.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IInverse`1
member.summary: A monoid which supports a unary inversion operator with respect to the associative binary operation.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IInverse`1.Inverse(`0)
member.summary:
Returns the inverse of the object. The inverse must fulfill the following for all X:
m.Op(X.Inverse, X) == m.Neutral (left-inverse) m.Op(X, X.Inverse) == m.Neutral (right-inverse)

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IIdempotent`1
member.summary:
A magma where performing the binary operation on an element X with itself results in that initial element, i.e.
m.Op(X, X) == X (idempotence)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.Ordered.Abs``3(``0,``2)
member.summary:
Returns the absolute value of an element , as defined via the piecewise function:
abs(x) = if x < 0 then negate(x) else x
Where < is defined by the total order, 0 is the neutral element of the first grouplike structure, and negate is the inverse-function of the first grouplike structure.
member.typeparam: The ringlike structure.
The first grouplike structure.
The type of the elements.
member.param: The element whose absolute value to get.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.ITransitiveRelation`1

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasLeftDistributive`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where the first operation left-distributes over the second, i.e.
X * (Y + Z) == (X * Y) + (X * Z)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasRightDistributive`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where the first operation right-distributes over the second, i.e.
(Y + Z) * X == (Y * X) + (Z * X)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasJacobi`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where which satisfy the Jacobi-identity, e.g.
X * (Y * Z) == (X * Y) * Z + Y * (X * Z)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasAnnihilation`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where the neutral element of the first operation annihiliates another element, if applied with the second operation, i.e.
0 * X = X * 0 = 0
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasRinglike`3
member.summary: General algebraic structures with two operations. The two operations are grouplike and there may be addition relationships between them, e.g. the second operation may distribute over the first.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasSemiring`3
member.summary: A semiring; a structure with two operations, where the first operation is a commutative monoid and the second operation is a monoid. In addition, the second operation, left- and right-distributes over the first and the neutral elemenent of the first operation is annihiliating in the second operation.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasNearRing`3
member.summary: A near-ring; a structure with two operations, where the first operation is a group and the second operation is a semigroup. In addition, the second operation, right-distributes over the first and the neutral elemenent of the first operation.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasRing`3
member.summary: A ring. Like a semiring, but the first operation forms a commutative group, i.e. subtraction is also defined.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasBooleanRing`3
member.summary: A Boolean ring; a ring where the second operation is idempotent.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasCommutativeRing`3
member.summary: A ring where the second operation is commutative.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasIntegralDomain`3
member.summary: A domain in which the product of two non-zero elements is also non-zero.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasGcdDomain`3
member.summary: A domain in which every two elements have a greatest common divisor or, equivalently, a least common multiple, through an efficient algorithm for finding them might not exist. See .
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasUniqueFactorizationDomain`3
member.summary: A domain in which every element can be uniquely factored into a product of prime elements.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasEuclideanDomain`3
member.summary: A domain which has an Euclidean division-function (every two elements X and Y can be divided, resulting in Divide(X,Y) = Q * Y + R.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasField`3
member.summary: A domain in which both operations form commutative groups, i.e. addition, multiplication, subtraction, and division (except for zero-divisors) are defined.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasFiniteField`3
member.summary: A field with finitely many elements.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasLattice`3
member.summary: A lattice, having a meet- and join-operation, which are commutative, associative, idempotent, and connected via the absorption-law.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasBoundedLattice`3
member.summary: A bounded lattice with a unique minimal and maximal element.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IHasDistributedLattice`3
member.summary: A distributed latter where the join and meet distribute over each other.
member.remarks: We cannot specify that the first operation should also distribute over the second (in addition to the second distributing over the first) via inheriting from and twice with and , since the C# forbids type parameter unification ( in the first instance of may be instantiated to the same type as in the second instance of , etc.). One could work around this, but the workaround was considered clunky and inconvenient to users, so we consciously omit trying to model both distributive laws in favor of just one.
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.ILeftDistributive`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where the first operation left-distributes over the second, i.e.
X * (Y + Z) == (X * Y) + (X * Z)

The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IRightDistributive`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where the first operation right-distributes over the second, i.e.
(Y + Z) * X == (Y * X) + (Z * X)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IJacobi`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where which satisfy the Jacobi-identity, e.g.
X * (Y * Z) == (X * Y) * Z + Y * (X * Z)
member.typeparam: The type of the carrier set.
The type of the first grouplike operation.
The type of the second groupike operation.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IAnnihilation`3
member.summary:
Ringlike structures where the neutral element of the first operation annihiliates another element, if applied with the second operation, i.e.
0 * X = X * 0 == 0

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Algebra.IEuclideanDomain`3.EuclideanDivide(`0,`0)
member.summary:
Performs Euclidean division on two elements and and returns a quotient q and a remainder r such that the following holds:
var (q, r) = r.Divide(x,y); x = y * q + r
if r.IsZero(y) is false.
member.example:
In the field of integers
r.Divide(138, 16) = (8, 10)

member.summary: A distributed latter where the join and meet distribute over each other.
member.remarks: We cannot specify that the first operation should also distribute over the second (in addition to the second distributing over the first) via inheriting from and twice with and , since the C# forbids type parameter unification ( in the first instance of may be instantiated to the same type as in the second instance of , etc.). One could work around this, but the workaround was considered clunky and inconvenient to users, so we consciously omit trying to model both distributive laws in favor of just one.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IAlternative`1
member.summary:
A subset of that has a notion of "combining computations". It's up to the implementor to define how this combining works, but implementors should obey the following laws:
x.Empty().Alt(a) == a (left-neutrality of Empty) a.Alt(x.Empty()) == a (right-neutrality of Empty) a.Alt(b).Alt(c) == a.Alt(b.Alt(c)) (associativity of Alt)
is thus a on . Moreover, the implementor should obey
x.Empty().Ap(a) == x.Empty() (guard)
Additionally, if the implementor implements , it should also obey:
x.Empty().Bind(f) == x.Empty()
member.remarks: serves two purposes: it functions as a monoid on instances of and it provides a "guard"-function which can stop a computation if it's not fulfilled. This is done via .
member.typeparam: The data contained in the functor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IApplicative`1
member.summary:
An applicative functor which supports applying multi-argument functions to containers. Implementations must fulfill the following (assuming that Pure(a) == X.Pure(a) for readability) for all a, f, g, h.
Pure(a).Ap(b => b) == Pure(a) (identity) Pure(a).Ap(Pure(f)) == Pure(f(a)) (homomorphism) Pure(a).Ap(f) == f.Ap(Pure(a => f(a))) (interchange) h.Ap(g).Ap(f) == h.Ap(g.Ap(f.Ap(Pure(comp)))) (composition) where comp f2 f1 x = f2(f1(x))
member.typeparam: The data contained in the functor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IComonad`1
member.summary: A comonad, which is the categorical dual of a . Whereas monads support the wrapping of values, comonads support their unwrapping.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IComonad`1.Extract
member.summary: Extracts a new value from the comonad.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IComonad`1.Extend``1(System.Func{Nordril.Functional.Category.IComonad{`0},``0})
member.summary:
Takes a function that extracts values from a comonad and chains it to this comonad by wrapping its result into a comonad. Implementros must fulfill the following for all X and f, g:
X.Extend(x => x.Extract()) = id (comonadic left-identity) X.Extend(f).Extract() = f (comonadic right-identity) X.Extend(g).Extend(f) = X.Extend(x => f(x.Extend(g))) (comonadic associativity)
Alternately, one can state these laws via Cokleisli composition =>=:
f =>= (x => x.Extract() = f (comonadic left-identity*) (x => x.Extract()) =>= f = f (comonadic right-identity*) (f =>= g) =>= h = f =>= (g =>= h) (comonadic associativity*)
For more detail, see https://hackage.haskell.org/package/comonad.
member.typeparam: The result of the function.
member.param: The function to chain to the comonad.

member.summary: Filters the container's elements, leaving the original unchanged and returning a version of the container which have the same structure as the original, but only with those elements which fulfill . What "leaving out elements" means exactly, depends on the implementor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.ISemifilterable`2
member.summary: Filterable data structures which do not support the removal of all elements. This is a weaker form of which does not support returning empty data structures if all elements have been excluded, but returns instead. An example is , which cannot represent empty trees, but which still supports a kind of filtering of its nodes.
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.
The type of element in the structure.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.ISemifilterable`2.Semifilter(System.Func{`1,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Filters the container's elements, leaving the original unchanged and returning a version of the container which have the same structure as the original, but only with those elements which fulfill . member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonad`1
member.summary: A monad. Monads, in addition to wrapping values (via and mapping over their contained values (via support temporarily unpacking their contained values and re-packing them via the operator. Unlike , this allows dynamically controlling the computational path at runtime, instead of just applying a fixed function over one of more wrapped arguments.
member.typeparam: The type of the values contained in the monad.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonad`1.Bind``1(System.Func{`0,Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonad{``0}})
member.summary:
Unpacks the value(s) contained in this monad and applies a function to them. Bind corresponds to chaining functions, with the addition of the monadic context. Implementors must fulfill the following laws:
Pure(a).Bind(f) == f(a) (left identity of pure) f.Bind(x => g(x).Bind(h)) == f.Bind(g).Bind(h) (associativity)
These laws are identical to the laws of , except for the type variable in .
member.typeparam: The type of the result.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.MonadExtensions.Join``1(Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonad{Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonad{``0}})
member.summary:
Flattens the structure of a monad. The following holds for all X and f, given a correctly implemented and :
X.Map(x => x.Join()).Join() = X.Join().Join() X.Map(x => x.Pure()).Join() = X.Pure().Join() = id X.Map(x => x.Map(f)).Join() = X.Join().Map(f)
member.typeparam: The type in the monad.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonadMorph`4
member.summary: A functor in the category of monads which offers the counterpart to .
member.remarks:
and are two ways of arriving at the same destination. If we have a value of type A, a monad M<A>, and a monad-transformer T<I, M,A>, we can go from A to T<I, M,A> over two "paths", as illustrated by this ASCII-diagram:
A -----[M.Pure]----> M<A> | | [I.Pure] [T.Lift] | | v v I<A> --[T.Hoist]--> T<M,A>
That is, if we have, say, a value of type , a monad , and a transformer (which is the transformer-version of ), then we can either
wrap the into and then into via , or
wrap the into , and then into via .
lift is thus used to lift "unrelated" computations into a monad transformer (like into ), whereas hoist is used to lift the "basic" version of computation into its transformer-form (like into ).
Formally, this interface is one morphism in a functor in the category of monads.
member.typeparam: The unlifted monadic value (e.g. IO<int>). This is used only by .
The type of the overall monadic value, e.g. IO<Maybe<int>>.
The inner monadic value, e.g. Maybe<int>.
The innermost source-type.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonadMorph`4.Hoist(`2)
member.summary: Hoist a value from the base form of the monad into its transformer-form, wrapping it, effectively, in a second monad.
member.param: The value in the inner monad to hoist.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonadPlus`1
member.summary: Monads that support choice (see ) in addition to failure (see ).

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonadPlus`1.Mplus(Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonadPlus{`0})
member.summary:
Adds two monad values. Implementors must fulfill the following for all X and a, b, c, and k:
X.Mzero.Mplus(a) = a (left identity) a.Mplus(X.mzero) = a (right identity) a.Mplus(b).Mplus(c) = a.Mplus(b.Mplus(c)) (associativity) a.Mplus(b).Bind(k) = a.Bind(k).Mplus(b.Bind(k)) (left-distribution)

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonadTransformer`4
member.summary: A monad transformer which wraps an inner monad () in an outer monad (), combining their semantics. Monad transformers are, here, also monads, enabling the usage of , , and , though they also provide monad-transformer-versions of these functions suffixed with "T". The only unique method of a monad transformer is , which takes a value from the unlifted monad and lifts it.
member.remarks: Monad transformers allow one to combine the functionality of a whole list/stack of monads, e.g. , , and in a single computation, though, in general, the order of wrapping matters, meaning OuterT<InnerT<A>> might have different semantics than InnerT<OuterT<A>>. Since monad transformers require higher-kinded types, the type parameters one has to specify are somewhat cumbersome due to CLR-limitations.
member.typeparam: The unlifted monadic value (e.g. IO<int>). This is used only by .
The type of the overall monadic value, e.g. IO<Maybe<int>>.
The inner monadic value, e.g. Maybe<int>.
The innermost source-type.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonoFunctor`2
member.summary:
Monofunctors. Monofunctors are like functors (see ), but they only support one specific type of element. An example would be a string, which is a monofunctor over char. Implementations have to obey the same laws as those of (for all X and f,g):
X.Map(a => a) == X (identity) X.Map(a => g(f(a))) == X.Map(f).Map(g) (homomorphism)
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.
The type of element contained in the monofunctor.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonoFunctor`2.MonoMap(System.Func{`1,`1})
member.summary: Applies a function to the values contained within the monofunctor and returns the result, without modifying the original object.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonoMonad`2
member.summary: A monad. Monads, in addition to wrapping values (via and mapping over their contained values (via support temporarily unpacking their contained values and re-packing them via the operator. Unlike , this allows dynamically controlling the computational path at runtime, instead of just applying a fixed function over one of more wrapped arguments.
member.typeparam: The type of the implementor.
The type of the values contained in the monad.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonoMonad`2.Pure(`1)
member.summary: Wraps a value into an applicative. The this-value MUST NOT BE USED by implementors.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IMonoMonad`2.Bind(System.Func{`1,`0})
member.summary:
Unpacks the value(s) contained in this monad and applies a function to them. Bind corresponds to chaining functions, with the addition of the monadic context. Implementors must fulfill the following laws:
Pure(a).Bind(f) == f(a) (left identity of pure) f.Bind(x => g(x).Bind(h)) == f.Bind(g).Bind(h) (associativity)
These laws are identical to the laws of , except for the type variable in .

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IPhantomFunctor`1
member.summary: A phantom-functor which is both a functor and a contravariant functor. Since a (covariant) functor and a contravariant functor to "the opposite things", one containing and one consuming values of type , the only way for any class to implement both is to not contain at all - hence, is only a phantom.
member.typeparam: The type of the values in the functor.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Category.IProfunctor`2
member.summary:
A functor that is contravariant in one type argument (meaning it needs values of that type) and covariant in its second type argument (meaning it contains values of that type). Implementors must fulfill the following for all X and f,g:
X.Promap(f, x => x) = X.Contramap(f) X.Promap(x => x, f) = X.Map(f)
member.typeparam: The type of values the functor needs.
The type of values the functor contains.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Category.IProfunctor`2.Promap``2(System.Func{``0,`0},System.Func{`1,``1})
member.summary: Applies a function to the contravariant part of the functor and another over its covariant one. If the profunctor taks A and produces B, then we apply two functions: one from NewA to A, and one from B to NewB. The result is a profunctor that takes NewA and produces NewB.
member.typeparam: The type of the new values the profunctor will need.
The type of the new values the profunctor will contain.
member.param: The function to apply to the contravariant values.
The function to apply to the covariant values.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.CollectionExtensions.AggregateRight``2(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,``1,``1},``1)
member.summary:
Performs a right-fold on a sequence. For associative combining functions , returns the same result as , though it will use heap memory linear in the length of . The definition is:
{x1,x2,...,xn}.AggregateRight(acc, f) = f(x1, f(x2, ... f(xn, acc)...) for instance {1, 2, 3, 4}.AggregateRight(0, (x, acc) => x + acc = 1 + (2 + (3 + (4 + 0)))
member.typeparam: The type of element in the sequence.
The type of the result/accumulator.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.CollectionExtensions.HashElements``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary:
Creates a hash value for a collection of elements by hashing the contained elements and adding them to a seed a multiplier. The hash code is computed by the formula:
collection.foldl(487, (acc, cur) => acc*31 + cur.GetHashCode())
Users should NOT rely on this implementation detail.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the collection.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.Either`2
member.summary: A sum type that can either be a left or a right, but not both. While left and right have no special semantics, per convention, the left is regarded as the "error-case", and the right is regarded as the "ok-case", if the either is used to model failure. Available as a data-source in LINQ-queries.
member.typeparam: The type of the left value in the either.
The type of the right value in the either.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Data.FuncSet`1.ReplaceEqualityComparer(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Conditionally returns either that or, if its is not reference-equals to ours, a copy with an equality-comparer that is reference-equals to ours. The point of this is so that set-theoretical operations use our equality-comparer instead of defaulting to reference-equality for elements if the equality-comparer of differs from ours (this behavior is from the .NET reference source). See https://referencesource.microsoft.com/system.core/system/Collections/Generic/HashSet.cs.html (AreEqualityComparersEqual and the functions which use it).
member.param: The set whose equality-comparer to replace.
member.returns: Either or a copy with its equality-comparer replaced.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.IFuncSet`1
member.summary: A "functional set" which, in addition to supporting the operations , implements (and parent interfaces).
member.remarks: Be aware that the equality comparer of the left set is used for determining element-equality for all set-theoretical operations. If the right set has a different equality comparer, this behavior will violate the expected theory of equivalence relations, e.g. you might have the situation where S.Equals(T) != T.Equals(S) or S.Except(T).UnionPure(T.Except(S)) != S.SymmetricDifferencePure(T). This is a conscious design choice, intended to allow you to use the equality comparer of your choice, and you should interpret all set-theoretical operations as modulo the equality comparer of the left set.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the set.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.Io`1
member.summary: A value which has an arbitrary computation (mainly Io) attached to it. This corresponds to , since in C#, any function can perform Io without declaring that fact in its type; however, this type enables one to build lazy pipelines via the -functionality, like mapping over the result while executing the attached action, run a multi-argument function over the results of computations, and composing functions. The boilerplate which this type takes care of is essentially that of function composition.
member.typeparam: The type of the result.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.IVisitable`2
member.summary:
Visitable structures which allow traversal of their elements, and the calling of a visit-function at each. For constructing visitors, see . Implementors must obey the following:
The order in which the elements of the structure are visited by is the same in which they would be folded.
member.typeparam: The type of element in the structure.
The type of the result.

member.returns: The structure-specific result.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.IForwardVisitable`3
member.summary: Visitable structures which signal when the traversal moves forward. only tells the visitor when an element is visited, but without any additional context. tells the visitor between which two elements the traversal is moving. On its own, this interface is not very useful and is more often appropriate, esp. with non-linear structures likes trees or graphs, where it might matter whence one comes and whither one moves. For constructing visitors, see .
member.typeparam: The type of element in the structure.
The type of element which indicates the target of a forward-movement. This might be the same as , or, say, a integer-index.
The type of the result.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Data.IForwardVisitable`3.VisitForward(Nordril.Functional.Data.IForwardVisitor{`0,`1})
member.summary:
Traverses the structure and calls the visitor at each element, and when moving forward from one element to the next. Implementors must make following operations identical (in the result and the observable effects, save for those caused by ):
x.Visit(v) and x.VisitForward(v)

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.IBackwardVisitable`3
member.summary: Visitable structures which signal when the traversal moves backward. only tells the visitor when an element is visited, but without any additional context. tells the visitor between which two elements the traversal is moving. On its own, this interface is not very useful and is more often appropriate, esp. with non-linear structures likes trees or graphs, where it might matter whence one comes and whither one moves. For constructing visitors, see .
member.typeparam: The type of element in the structure.
The type of element which indicates the target of a backward-movement. This might be the same as , or, say, a integer-index.
The type of the result.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Data.IBackwardVisitable`3.VisitBackward(Nordril.Functional.Data.IBackwardVisitor{`0,`1})
member.summary:
Traverses the structure and calls the visitor at each element, and when moving backwards from one element to the previous. Implementors must make following operations identical (in the result and the observable effects, save for those caused by ):
x.Visit(v) and x.Reverse.VisitBackward(v)

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.Memo`3
member.summary: A memoization-monad which allows one to run computations that make use of memoization of the results. This generally makes sense for recursive functions with overlapping subproblems where we only want to compute f(x) = y the first time and retrieve its stored result y whenever a subsequent call to f(x) is made. The main function to use with this structure is . The memoization is backed by a finite . Commonly, there is no limit on the number of computed results to store, though one can limit this via a custom dictionary-implementation.
member.typeparam: The type of the state.
The type of the key by which results are memoized.
The type of the value which is computed.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Data.Tree.RetrieveDirectoryStructure(System.String,Nordril.Functional.Data.PathNameUsage,System.Func{System.String,System.Boolean})
member.summary:
Takes a directory and returns a tree representing that directory as its root and the sub-directories and files as child-nodes, recursively. An represents a directory and will always be an inner-node, and an represents a file. No file will have a directory as a child.
This method uses direct recursion and thus required O(n) stack space, where n is the maximum depth of the directory structure. Symlinks are not traversed. As there are no filesystem-level locks, this method may fail if a file or directory is deleted partway through the computation.
member.param: Where to use the full names of filesystem-entries.
The optional predicate to which a path (except for the root-node) has to conform to be included as a node. The argument is always the full path of the filesystem-entry.
member.exception: If the directory does not exist.
A directory path is invalid, such as referring to an unmapped drive or having been deleted.
The specified path, file name, or combined exceed the system-defined maximum length.
The caller does not have the required permission.
The caller does not have the required permission.
If the maximum stack size has been exceeded.

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Data.Writer`3
member.summary: The writer-monad, which provides write-only access to a state, in addition to producing a result. The output can then be later extracted, but not by the computations within the writer-monad themselves.
member.typeparam: The type of the output.
The type of the result.
The monoid on used to combine the outputs. This MUST be a type whose - and -operations DO NOT use the this-pointer, i.e. NOT a generic -instance, but some user-made -instance.
member.remarks: The two main functions one can use with a writer are tell (which stores a new output in the state of the writer) and listen (which stores a new output in the state of the writer and also returns it as the writer's result). Due to limits of type-inference, using and are quite cumbersome; for this reason, specialized versions are provided in the form of (as a specialized replacement for ; and (as a specialized replacement for ).

member.name: T:Nordril.Functional.Pattern
member.summary: A constructor for a first-class pattern.
member.remarks:
Using a consists of two stages:
Constructing a list of cases which are checked in-order, and
running the pattern against an input object.
Constructing a case-list is a safe operation in that none of the cases are evaluated, though be advised that the -object is not thread-safe and should be used prior to sharing it across threads. Each case consists of a predicate which has to evaluate to true if the case is to apply, and an action which is run on the input object if the case applies.
Cases can be added via a fluent-API, all at once or at different times. s, being first-class objects, can be passed in as arguments or be returned by functions.
The second stage is the exection: via , and input-object is passed in and the previously registered cases are evaluated in order of their addition. The first case which evaluates to true is applied and result of its action returned; if no cases applies, the default pattern is applied, which can be set via . If no default pattern was set and no case applies, a is thrown.
It is considered good form to always specify a default pattern unless one is absolutely sure that the disjunction of the registered cases all possible values of the input object.

member.summary: Appends a new case to the end of a . The calling object will be modified and this will be returned.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Pattern`2.Match(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.ValueTuple{System.Func{`0,System.Boolean},System.Func{`0,`1}}})
member.summary: Appends a list of new cases to the end of a . The calling object will be modified and this will be returned.

member.name: M:Nordril.Functional.Pattern`2.MatchTailRec(System.Func{`0,System.Boolean},System.Func{`0,`0})
member.summary:
Appends a new, tail-recursive case to the end of a . The calling object will be modified and this will be returned. Note that a tail-recursive case cannot be a terminating case and if the input-object always matches a tail-recursive case, will not terminate.
Instead of returning an output, it returns an -object with which the pattern-match will be called tail-recursively. This means that no new stack-frame will be allocated for the recursive call. Think of this like running a pattern-match in a loop. For general recursion (which runs the risk of stack overflows), see the examples in .
member.remarks: If tail-recursion is all you need, using is actually superior to a native switch-expression with a recursive call in it (w.r.t. the consumption of stack-memory) because the C# runtime does not support tail-recursion. Of course, any tail-recursive switch-expression can be easily transformed into one which does not run into a stack overflow (becsause of the recursion alone) by floating out the recursion into a loop around the the switch.
member.param: The predicate which returns true if the case applies.
The function that should be applied to the input object if the case applies.

member.summary: Sets the default pattern which always applies after all other cases. This call overwrites any previously set default pattern, except if null is passed in , in which case nothing is done.

member.summary: Runs a pattern against an input object and returns the result of the first case that applies, or the result of the default pattern is none applies.
member.returns: The result of the first case which applies to the input object, with that case's action run against the input object.
member.exception: If no case applies and no alternative default pattern was set via .
